image.altText: A close-up shot of WA Premier Mark McGowan speaking at a media conference indoors in front of a blonde woman.

items.synopsis: WA Premier Mark McGowan abruptly resigns from politics in an unexpected announcement at a press conference, saying the job has left him "extremely tired".

title.children: 'I'm exhausted': WA Premier Mark McGowan in shock decision to resign from politics

image.altText: A man with a blue checked shirt

items.synopsis: WA Premier Mark McGowan has announced his resignation from politics in a surprise announcement. Follow live.

title.children: 'I didn't see it coming': Nation reacts to Mark McGowan’s shock resignation

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: By reporter Cason Ho: WA Liberal Leader Libby Mettam says Mark McGowan made a “significant contribution” to the state over his nearly-three decades in public life. “Being given the opportunity to serve is an honour and a privilege, but it can undoubtedly take its toll,” she said. “We have always questioned why the premier had undertaken the role of treasurer as well, given the significant size of the caucus that WA Labor has enjoyed.” Ms Mettam said, despite Mr McGowan’s popularity, his resignation made no difference to her party’s plans at the next election. “The Liberals have always seen the next state election as contestable,” she said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Opposition leader applauds McGowan's 'significant contribution'

children.content: By reporter Cason Ho:
WA Liberal Leader Libby Mettam says Mark McGowan made a “significant contribution” to the state over his nearly-three decades in public life.
“Being given the opportunity to serve is an honour and a privilege, but it can undoubtedly take its toll,” she said.
“We have always questioned why the premier had undertaken the role of treasurer as well, given the significant size of the caucus that WA Labor has enjoyed.”
WA Liberal Leader Libby Mettam
(ABC News: Ashleigh Davis)
Ms Mettam said, despite Mr McGowan’s popularity, his resignation made no difference to her party’s plans at the next election.
“The Liberals have always seen the next state election as contestable,” she said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: WA Opposition and Nationals leader Shane Love said Mr McGowan’s resignation would “come at a cost” to the WA Labor party, which has enjoyed overwhelming popularity in recent years. “There’s no doubt that the McGowan name was very much the brand of this particular Labor government,” he said. Mr Love said the premier’s decision to appoint himself as the state’s treasurer after winning the 2021 state election likely put him under undue pressure. “It certainly was a role that he could have selected someone else to do. That, no doubt, would also have added to his workload."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Resignation to 'come at a cost' to WA Labor

children.content: WA Opposition and Nationals leader Shane Love said Mr McGowan’s resignation would “come at a cost” to the WA Labor party, which has enjoyed overwhelming popularity in recent years.
“There’s no doubt that the McGowan name was very much the brand of this particular Labor government,” he said.
WA Opposition Leader Shane Love.
(ABC News)
Mr Love said the premier’s decision to appoint himself as the state’s treasurer after winning the 2021 state election likely put him under undue pressure.
“It certainly was a role that he could have selected someone else to do. That, no doubt, would also have added to his workload."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Surrounded by his cabinet at the press conference, Mr McGowan said the "relentless" pressures of political life had worn him down. "I've loved the challenge of solving problems, making decisions, getting outcomes, and helping people," he said. "It comes with huge responsibility that is all consuming each and every day. And, combined with the COVID years, it's taken it out of me." Mr McGowan said he still believed in the Labor party, and had confidence it would win the next state election. 'I'm convinced WA Labor can win, and will win … but I just don't have the energy or drive that's required to continue in the role as premier," he said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: McGowan: 'Relentless' pressure has worn me down

children.content: Surrounded by his cabinet at the press conference, Mr McGowan said the "relentless" pressures of political life had worn him down.

props.alt: A man shuts his eyes and looks down at a press conference

children.content: Mark McGowan says he is 'exhausted'.
(ABC News: Keane Bourke)
"I've loved the challenge of solving problems, making decisions, getting outcomes, and helping people," he said.
"It comes with huge responsibility that is all consuming each and every day. And, combined with the COVID years, it's taken it out of me."
Mr McGowan said he still believed in the Labor party, and had confidence it would win the next state election.
'I'm convinced WA Labor can win, and will win … but I just don't have the energy or drive that's required to continue in the role as premier," he said.

image.altText: Brendan Godfrey looks at the camera.

items.synopsis: A man who has pleaded guilty to menacing another man via social media says he and an associate did it because the victim was posting misinformation about COVID-19 online — something which angered him as he was awaiting a kidney transplant.
